B000002UAC|5.0|This is the album that launched Beatlemania in the U.S.  Well, sort of.  The cover is the same, but this is the U.K. version of the Beatles' second album, which was released only eight months after their debut in March of 1963. The U.S. version (entitled Meet the Beatles) included only nine of these songs and added &quot;I Want To Hold Your Hand&quot; and its b-side &quot;I Saw Her Standing There&quot; along with &quot;This Boy.&quot;<br />But even though this is not the version that millions of baby boomers (like myself) grew up with, it's still an essential album in the Beatles' catalog.  Among the originals is their best song never released as a single, &quot;All My Loving.&quot; Also Ringo gets a vocal on the song originally given to the Rolling Stones, &quot;I Wanna Be Your Man.&quot;  And George Harrison gets his first songwriting credit with &quot;Don't Bother Me.&quot;<br />The Beatles raid the Motown vaults for many of the covers.  &quot;Please Mr. Postman,&quot; &quot;You've Really Got a Hold on Me&quot; and &quot;Money&quot; are highlights.  The latter features one of Lennon's best vocals. [It wouldn't be until their next album when they released a collection of all original material.]<br />All told, this album catches the Beatles while they are still not too far removed from their Cavern Club and Hamburg days. As such, you hear an urgency and energy in their performance that sets their music apart from the rest of the British Invasion that followed. ESSENTIAL

In an ethereal aspect, \\"Mulholland Drive\\" is a hypnotic film that has a trance like effect on all of your senses.  It soothes, compels, disorients, intoxicates, frustrates, excites, frightens, and teases. While the movie portrays Marla as secondary - a distraction from the pursuits of manhood, she is a central figure in the book. B00006CXXU|4.0|Let's get this clear, Ms Aguilera is no pop-puppet (or so she would have us believe). With 'Stripped' X-Tina clearly places herself beyond the other peroxide blonde pop-robots in the industry (and yes, Jessica Simpson, Mandy Moore et all I do mean you). Britney may \\"not be a girl, not yet a woman' but Christina Aguilera has no such doubts, this is one chick who certainly knows who she is, and then some.<BR> <BR>At 20 tracks long the record is hard work, but surprisingly there are no weak tracks. Not afraid to embrace diverse musical styles from the hip-hop of the Red Man featuring Dirrty, to the samba beats of Make Over, Stripped clearly is a record that is not just meant for the pre-pubescent market. Tackling various issues from sexism in the music industry to the public humiliation she has received from the likes of a certain Marshall Mathers III, Stripped remains dignified by never becoming pretensious, and knowing at its heart its just a pop  record. Unlike her debut album, Stripped is largely devoid of the vocal gymnastics (ie singing 12 notes when one will do), with ballads suchs as Loving Me 4 Me signalling a new found vocal maturity. <br />Highlights of the album include the Alicia Keys collabo Impossible and the sheer funk of opener Can't Hold Us Down. Featuring guest artists from Lil'Kim to Dave Navarro and the aforementioned Red-Man, make no mistake, this album is all Aguilera, with her taking many co-writing and production credits. <br />Stripped is simply a great pop record thats not afraid to shake off the innocent girl image that dogs so many of Aguilera's peers. Though not revolutionary in anyway, and slightly predicatble (why does artistic maturity always equate with wearing less clothes in your videos anyway?), this is a polished effort packed with hits, and in short the sort of album that Mariah Carey can now only dream off.

Because \\"Boo\\" Radley has not been seen in years, the two are in awe over his mystery.  To Kill a Mockingbird is told through the eyes of young Scout.  Acting very mature in conversation, Scout does not let on that she is only eight years old.  In reality, Scout does not understand what the accused rapist, Tom Robinson, has done. B00005JKZ3|3.0|Okay, so this may not be a patch on the original movie and a may have a weak plot that would struggle to fill a half hour TV show but it's also nowhere near as bad as most people have made it out to be and still has it's high points and amusing moments.<br />Five years after the original hit movie Men in Black took movie theatres across the world by storm, the world eagerly awaited Barry Sonnenfield's follow up which reunited the hit pairing of Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith. What the world expected was another hour and a halves worth of comedy and kickin'...action. What we get is a plot that, much like the original, has an alien villain, Serleena  (Lara Flynn Boyle) endangering Earth's population and the future of our planet, in her quest for the Light of Zartha. As it so happens, the only person who knows where the light is hidden is Agent K (Tommy Lee Jones) but he's now working in a Maine post office and completely unaware of his MIB past, having been neuralized at the end of the first movie, leaving Agent J (Will Smith) to set about retrieving both K and his memory before it's too late. Cue a glorious laugh riot and lots of fun action. Well, you would hope so but....<br />One of the problems with sequels is that they invariably have so much weight of expectation but with the very odd exception (Godfather II, Empire Strikes Back etc.), they nearly always fail to be a match for the original and in some cases, such as Escape From LA, Highlander 2 and A Nightmare on Elm Street 2, they can be just plain awful. Many sequels just try to copy the successful formula of the original, missing out all the talent, originality, wit and imagination that went into making the original movie such a hit in the first place. Unfortunately to a great extent is the case with MIB 2, with many of the scenes and much of the plot being too similar to the original movie.<br />MIB II is in the end all action and FX but it is also generally uninspired and less entertaining than the original. I also think it missed Linda Fiorentino's presence but having said that, it does have its moments and it does have some good laughs: The high point of the movie is perhaps seeing Agent K as a militant postmaster complete with comedy shorts and long socks, as opposed to the cool black suit and shades of he usually wears and some of the scenes with Frank (the dog) are also amusing. However, that's about as good as it gets and seldom does it rise above average. Don't get me wrong though, this is not a bad movie, I did find it entertaining and it's hardly going to damage anybody's career. Most kids will love this regardless of its faults BUT although entertained my overwhelming memory of this movie is a sense of d&eacute;j&agrave; vu.inal. B000002R6A|1.0|Eric Burdon and the New Animals stumbled into the latter half of 1968 dogged by internal ruptures, fading sales and way too much studio time on their hands. So what does Burdon do? He decides to record a double album dominated by hoary psychedelic covers with an under-rehearsed band. I loaned this to a friend of mine to see how far he could get through it. He raised the white flag somewhere during &quot;Colored Rain.&quot; The band's clumsiness forces Burdon to do what he does worst, and that is fill gaps with hysterically longwinded vocal improvisations. Exhibit A: &quot;River Deep Mountain High.&quot; Instead of sticking with the listenable 3:52 45 version, LOVE IS expands the cut to well over 7:00 so we can listen to Eric pant riotously over Tina Turner. And that's one of the shorter tracks. Zoot Money contributes the sublimely ridiculous &quot;Gemini (The Madman),&quot; a 19-minute remake of a Dantalian's Chariot curio complete with spoken word section. It's guaranteed to clear the house of unwanted visitors or your money back. It's so awful it transcends unlistenable, it transcends camp, it transcends stupidity to arrive in an eden of delirium that's not all that different from the territory Arthur Lee charted, except Love marched triumphantly through the front door whereas these guys stumbled in from the rear end. BTW, Andy Summers was a New Animal at this point, but anyone seeking examples of the idiosyncratic guitar work he brought to the Police will hear here what he learned not to do musically. After striking out on cut after cut, Burdon finally manages a double with a good, soulful cover of the Bee Gees' &quot;To Love Somebody&quot; that acts as reminder of what a great vocalist he is when he's not singing hungover hippie gunk or ruining good songs with listless, hammy arrangements. I suspect the only reason Burdon got away with releasing this was because he was one of the few legitmate rock stars on MGM's talent roster at that time (You were thinking perhaps, the Osmonds?). Fortunately, our faith in Eric was restored when he rebounded from this fiasco to work with War. But if you must know why the Animals finally crumbled, buy this CD. Listen to the whole thing if you dare. Then, dare your friends! Hold wagers on how long one can hold out before demanding asprin. (No offense Eric, but this album is rotten.) To be fair, a truly pure spirit could treasure this record the way a real searcher may overcome innate artistic prejudice and common sense to find something true and meaningful in the music of Michael Bolton. Of course, that searcher isn't me.
B00006CXXU|5.0|Christina Aguilera's new album, \\"Stripped\\" is the best CD yet to be put out by this tiny vocal powerhouse.  I have nothing more to say than the fact that this is one of the finest recordings I have heard to be categorized as 'today's' music.  She infuses almost every style of music out there, and executes rhythms and vocals with expertise and poise.  She has come a long way since 'Genie In A Bottle.'  I highly recommend this album to anyone looking for a fresh, new sound from an 'old' favorite.

0316666343|3.0|As you probably know by now, \\"The Lovely Bones\\" by Alice Sebold begins with the rape and murder of 14-year-old Susie Salmon in a town in Pennsylvania, and the rest of the novel is told from her point of view as she observes the aftermath from her omniscient vantage point in heaven.  That she can narrate the inner thoughts of different characters as they deal with the shock of her death is the best part of the book.  I've never had to deal with such a shocking loss in my life but the reactions of the other characters ring true to me and are sometimes very moving.  In addition, Ms. Sebold's portrayal of Susie's experience in heaven is interesting and, um, plausible (not sure how else to describe it, but it is an appealing vision).<br />Susie also delves into side stories like the sacrifices her once-ambitious mother makes for her family, and the troubled childhood of the man who murdered her, and continues to follow her family and friends for years after her death.  This isn't bad in itself but the sentimentality of the later chapters failed to warm my cynical heart, after I was taken in by the first half of the book and the stunned reaction of the town after the murder.  The captivating intensity fades and the book falters, in my opinion.  The prose has a few nice flourishes but is mostly straightforward; the characters' development slows to a halt and left me feeling they weren't fleshed out enough.  If either of these aspects had been meatier I think the book would have had more staying power with me.<br />Nevertheless, there are still enough chilling and memorable moments in the \\"The Lovely Bones\\" to make it a worthwhile read.  It's a nice first novel and my uninformed opinion is that Ms. Sebold's got the talent to produce even more moving and perceptive novels in the future.

B000002UDB|5.0|After \\"Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band\\" The Beatles were musically unstoppable. While \\"Sgt. Pepper\\" was clearly a great album, \\"Magical Mystery Tour\\" is no less great but got caught between \\"Sgt. Pepper\\" and \\"The White Album\\", both of which are considered groundbreaking. I suppose that eventually you run out of superlatives in describing three outstanding albums in a row from one group. However, it is this quality that made The Beatles the greatest rock group of all time.<br />The album kicks off with \\"Magical Mystery Tour\\", which is as innovative and musically interesting as the song \\"Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band\\". In addition to being novel, this song was featured in an extended music video that featured the songs from the first half of the album. One of the interesting features of this album was the number of songs that had little or nothing to do with love and girls, delving instead into subjects tending toward the psychedelic, such as this song does.<br />\\"The Fool on the Hill\\" is a song that shows that even though The Beatles music was generally becoming more complex, they could create relatively simple masterpieces. This song is John Lennon and Paul McCartney at their creative best.<br />\\"Flying\\", attributed to all four, is an unusual instrumental that again has a bit of psychedelic feel to it. A good fit with the tv show.<br />\\"Blue Jay Way\\" is a perfect fit with 60s psychedelic music. The music was simple, but the bizarre sound of some other psychedelic music. Note that this song led many of the other groups that tried to create similar music in 1968 and 1969. This song is a good indicator of the direction that George Harrison was heading in his life and his music.<br />\\"Your Mother Should Know\\" is relatively simple compared to the songs surrounding it. More like pop, but in this context it provides the reference for how psychedelic the other songs really were.<br />\\"I Am the Walrus\\" is one of the all-time great psychedelic songs that set the stage for much progressive rock that followed. The song has lyrics that almost make sense, and do if you try not to decipher it word for word. It was music like this that was the basis for Yes in the creation of \\"Tales from Topographic Oceans\\". Sounds carrying meaning independent of the actual usage of the words.<br />From this point forward the songs were added to complete an albums worth of material. And what great songs these were. Generally pop songs, but with Beatle's class, every one a classic and great. Two things worthy of additional note: First, \\"Strawberry Fields Forever\\" is a very well done pop ballad that is classic Beatles, and another of the songs that show how perfect John Lennon and Paul McCartney were as a team. The other is that \\"All You Need Is Love\\" was the first world-wide satellite broadcast of a show, and an indication of the popularity and success of The Beatles.<br />Perhaps overlooked by some, but one of The Beatles' greats, this album is a combination of a concept (the first half), and a collection of singles. Quality in every song, this one is a must-have for any Beatles or 60s music fan.stage for much progressive rock that followed. The song has lyrics that almost make sense, and do if you try not to decipher it word for word. It was music like this that was the basis for Yes in the creation of \\"Tales from Topographic Oceans\\". Sounds carrying meaning independent of the actual usage of the words.<br />From this point forward the songs were added to complete an albums worth of material. And what great songs these were. The other is that \\"All You Need Is Love\\" was the first world-wide satellite broadcast of a show, and an indication of the popularity and success of The Beatles.<br />Perhaps overlooked by some, but one of The Beatles' greats, this album is a combination of a concept (the first half), and a collection of singles. Quality in every song, this one is a must-have for any Beatles or 60s music fan.
B00005JKJA|1.0|Tempting though it may be to use my allotted 1,000 words to thoroughly trash this perverse, voyeuristic cinematic drivel, I shall instead be brief. This seems to be one of those artistic creations that people tend to either love or hate. Count me firmly in the latter category. In several decades of avid movie viewing, rarely have I so regretted wasting my time and money on a film. I'll admit that the first half of \\"Mulholland Drive\\" seduced me into thinking, hoping, desiring a big payoff in the second half. But it was just a tease. The second half marks as rapid a descent into nihilistic depravity and madness as I've ever witnessed (and hope never to witness again). However, I can't claim I wasn't warned - after all, it was no secret that this was a David Lynch creation. Given the apparently uniformly raving critical response to this film, I felt compelled to make it known that not everyone concurs. I consider myself fairly intelligent and open-minded, but I just can't help assessing \\"Mulholland Drive\\" as a pot-holed dead end.

B00006LLNU|5.0|Sigur Ros are a blend of sounds the like of which you will not find elsewhere. With a dedicated fan-base as diverse as Radiohead (who cited them as an influence on Kid A) and Cameron Crowe (who included three songs in his movie Vanilla Sky), this could be the album that finally earns them the widespread recognition that they deserve. Their second album Agaetis Byrjun was a monumental epic that created a new sound. This third album consists of studio versions of songs that have been honed over the last two years during live performances. Their previous albums have been in Icelandic; this latest one is in Hopelandic, a made-up quasi-gibberish that allows lead singer Jon thor Birgisson (Jonsi) to project his voice (half-way between choir-boy and Thom Yorke) almost as an instrument. Incidentally, the lack of lyrics allows each listener to conclude what each song means to him personally, and your interpretations can be posted on the web alongside other fans'. The tracks are also untitled, though many of them carry unofficial monikers. With any other band this would be an act of extreme pretence, but as a Sigur Ros fan it is hard to conclude that it could have been done any other way. Even the album itself is untitled, simply named ( ), which can be interpreted as symbolising the two distinct halves that complete the whole, or it could be on a similar theme to the interpretive lyrics, in that you should fill in your own album title. Track 1, sometimes referred to as Vaka, is the one they most commonly kick off their concerts with, and it is an appropriately slow track that utilised a calm piano riff. Track 2, Fyrsta, is again a beautifully-constructed track that is more mournful, almost lethargic. Track 3, Samskeyti, for lack of other words can be described as unbelievably pretty, and uplifting as it combines once again a simple piano riff with strings, in what is an instrumental piece. Track 4, Njsnavlin, is perhaps the most famous song off the new album: it was used in the climactic scene of Vanilla Sky, and was performed on Kilbourn. The first studio version combines all the best aspects of the various forms it has appeared on stage, and adds an accompaniment that at once achieves perfection. Track 4 is followed by a silenec that allows the mood of the album to totally shift. When it restarts with lafoss, it is much more downbeat in tone, but no less masterfully-constructed for it. The songs effortlessly segue into one another as E-Bow and The Death Song go by, as it gears towards the climactic Track 8: Popplagi. Unlike anything else they have ever composed, 'The Pop Song' rocks out with an intensity unlike anything else I have heard. The various elements just come together in perfect unison to achieve a perfect blend of emotion and intensity that leave you reeling as the CD comes to a close. Appropriately, Sigur Ros are in the habit of ending their sets with this track. The final lyrics of Agaetis Byrjun made reference to how this was a Good Beginning (the literal translation of the album title), but that they will do better this time. On this evidence, they keep getting better...
B00006V9A0|5.0|When I bought this CD my initial thought was to give it a mixed review based on the fact that it only has one new song and only 14 tracks total. B00006LLNU|5.0|This has to be one of the most intense albums I have listened to in ages. The sadness that permeates the air when this album is being played is staggering! It is near impossible to pick out one particular track from the other, instead this albums songs meld into one. Each movement has it's own distinct feel yet all songs run along the same theme, the same flow of utter desolation. The result is a very solid and effective album and one that should not be ignored. A graceful yet powerful beast that creeps up inside you and fails to release it's grasp even after it's 70 minutes has completed it's revolution.

0767802470|5.0|The title says it all. If you can watch this film without being moved by the suffering and horror that these young submariners had to endure (regardless of the twisted ideology that sent them to war) there's something badly wrong with you. Insightful, gritty, with believable, human characters (Jurgen Prochnow was born to the role of the captain, but the entire sub crew are immaculately cast) thoughtfully presented and beautifully shot, with a haunting score. This is not another preachy 'war is hell' (so what else is new?) kind of film. It's a great film, period, and in it's own sad way, very uplifting. The directors cut is outstanding, and I found the commentary rivetting. If you appreciated Das Boot, I'd recommend you check out 'Stalingrad', in the unlikely even that you haven't already. Admittedly, it's an almost unremittingly grim and brutal experience, so not for the faint hearted, but a fine film nontheless.

0316666343|2.0|What happened to this novel?  It started off wonderfully and grabbed me from the first chapter (read it here at Amazon and see if you don't agree) - I can see why the publisher wanted it in print.  But each chapter thereafter gets duller, more mundane, and - especially in the last 100 pages - downright inane.<br />I don't doubt Ms. Sebold's talent as a writer, but it seems obvious she had no idea how to end the book - and still doesn't.<br />One other note: you need to be able to handle metaphors that make absolutely no sense whatsoever.  Doesn't Little Brown have editors anymore?  I can only hope whoever writes the screenplay (I assume this is going to film) will rewrite the second half of the story.
B00005A46T|5.0|Slipknot's IOWA is a jaw breaking, mosh pittin', heavy metal musical massacre that is probably one of the best metal albums of that year. Unlike many other bands today, no re-hashed chords or melodies were used and this album proved that no matter what, you can count on Slipknot to be organic every single time instead of re-releasing a previous album and calling it new material like some of those other guys.<br />This one keeps you going. For me personally, it's very rare when a band makes a CD that I can listen to all the way through not skipping any songs. I did that on the self title SLIPKNOT and now again on IOWA. <br />Usually lightning doesn't strike the same place twice but I assure you that this one has. Get IOWA and if you're trying to catch up, make sure to pick up the self title SLIPKNOT as well.

B000002UB3|5.0|Abbey Road is the last album the Beatles ever recorded as a group.  <br />I think the interesting thing about this album is how on side one we have each of the Beatles doing more or less their own thing...<br />Lennon does his nonsense funk-hard rock (Come Together) his hypnotizing post-psychedelic harmony (Because) and the vastly underrated &quot;I Want You (She's so Heavy)&quot; which may have his simplest lyrics ever but he turns them into desperatly powerful statements with a couple great guitar and bass riffs and an amazing vocal performances that alters power and tenderness.<br />Harrison only pens two songs but he proves his worthiness by making them 2 of the albums 3 most famous tracks...the exquisite &quot;Here Comes the Sun&quot; and the famous &quot;Something.&quot;  He would continue this success with his solo debut &quot;All Things Must Pass&quot; which contains many songs he had written back in the Abbey Road era.<br />McCartney takes a back seat (relatively speaking) for side one, only throwing in the happy-go-lucky &quot;Maxwell's Silver Hammer&quot; which may well be one of his catchiest songs ever, the vocal-shredding a la Helter Skelter &quot;Oh! Darling&quot; and the quietly attractive &quot;You Never Give Me Your Money.&quot;  Certainly not the most famous of McCartney's Beatle tunes, but they are all good tracks.<br />Ringo is represented by his 2nd written song ever, &quot;Octopus's Garden&quot;.  In typical Ringo fashion its catchy, pleasant, and simple.<br />...But on side two we have the Beatles seemingly back as a cohesive unit, with their ever-famous suite of song fragments, all of them good ones, and with each Beatle doing their part.  Ringo pens a rare drum solo or 2, Lennon being fun without losing his creativity in Sun King/Mean Mr Mustard/Polythene Pam, Paul proving hes no slouch either with the beautiful She Came in Through the Bathroom Window/Golden Slumbers/Carry That Weight, and &quot;The End&quot; bringing the Beatles together in their glory.<br />Only George seems to have taken a back seat on this one, but in typical Beatles fashion; he only penned 2-3 songs on any Beatles album.  But he sure made the best of his chances!
B000058983|5.0|Denying the emotion in this album denies everything you have ever felt about music. Not only do the songs on Forever Changes display the turmoil and confusion of the time it was made, it can equally be brandished for the world today. Sure there's better albums out there, but this is one that stands seperate from the others through it's sheer creativity. This isn't the San Francisco psychedelic sound, this is pure L.A. manic music, the dark side of the hippie movement. It deserves a alot more recognition, nothing else sounds like this. I own all the &quot;classic&quot; albums and this remains to be a favorite of mine. As for calling it dated, I can't see why, the songs here linger for what seems like forever. &quot;You Set the Scene&quot; embodies what makes music worthwhile: complexity, emotion, and revelation. And please, the whole &quot;snot&quot; thing - it's a literary device called imagery. The album's called Forever Changes and that's excactly what it's about, change. If changes are too difficult for you, then go listen to something primitive and deny yourself a fantastic album.

B00006V9A0|3.0|Where Courtney could have given up some of her so cherished CREATIVE CONTROL, we are blessed/cursed with a disc of Nirvana's best, featuring a really creative album title (all of the disputes are cleared? yeah, right!) and a bunch of songs that the Nirvana completists and probably the passing fans already have. The new song, \\"You Know You're Right\\", probably is the last great Nirvana song and it really is worth having. That said, while they're scant, there are a few rarities for the completists. The slower version of \\"Been A Son\\", originally from the Blew EP, makes an appearance as does the 'previously unreleased' Scott Litt remix of \\"Pennyroyal Tea\\" (it was never officially released but copies of the never-released import single featuring it were leaked and the track has circulated since). Personally, I prefer the album version but it's nice to have it since it's not an easy find.<br />So, in closing, 2 things: #1, this disc is really an okay starting point for new fans as it features ALL the singles/hits and a few must have tracks (I'm glad Rape Me and the original version of About A Girl made the list and You Know You're Right really is great!) but it doesn't serve enough depth for the longtime fans or anyone that really wants to know about the band. And, #2, why the hell did they put \\"Dumb\\" on instead of \\"Polly\\"? Who made that decision? This could've been a great oportunity to make a compilation that PROPERLY covered their entire career but instead we get a corporate greatest hits compilation! Courtney has shown she's the same as the corporate rock industry that Kurt always faught against, rehashing for the almighty dollar. I would've gladly paid for the proposed box set but instead I got just about everything I already had with only one thing I REALLY wanted. Beware.

Is it really important to have a new car? Or a new house? Or new clothes or whatever your heart desires? When you are on your deathbed, are you going to have a lot of regrets or are you going to celebrate your life as it was and move on? <br />Also, this book tackles the touchy subject of death ~~ something most people tend to avoid talking let alone think about. 0743216458|2.0|I picked up &quot;Band of Brothers&quot; for two reasons: first, I have been hearing for years what a great historian Stephen Ambrose was; second, I loved the HBO series and thought the book would provide deeper insights into the men of Easy Company and their WWII experience.  How surprised I was to discover just the opposite.  Ambrose may have been a great historian, but he was no writer.  Incidents that in the series were presented with drama and suspense were written of in a flat-footed, perfunctory manner.  What I came away with most after reading &quot;Band of Brothers&quot; was less respect for Ambrose and more for the producers and writers of the series, who so successfully fleshed out Ambrose's skeletal text.  I don't think I've ever said this before, but skip the book and rent the movie.
B000008GEF|5.0|George Harrison is, hands-down, the most underrated figure in the history of popular music, and the most deeply moving songwriter of the twentieth century.  If you are not convinced, this album, a true masterpiece by the highest of musically standards.  If you like &quot;catchy&quot; pop/rock tunes, chances are you will be pleased with &quot;Living In The Material World&quot;, but it is for those how can truly appreciate slower, heart-touching ballads that this album will simply blow away all others.  In the opinion of my high school music teacher and mentor, &quot;L.I.T.M.W.&quot; is, without question, the true pinnacle of popular music, and I know that this opinion is shared by other musical authorities with respect for serious, moving music.<BR>     Enough cannot be said about the albums equisite musical underpinning.  Nicky Hopkins and Gary Wright provide truly lovely piano work, and John Barham's glorious orchestral arrangements splendidly back Harrison's masterpieces of composition.  The total effect is awesome on songs such as &quot;The Light That Has Lighted The World&quot;, &quot;The Day The World Gets Round&quot;, &quot;That Is All&quot;, and even the upbeat #1 hit single &quot;Give Me Love (Give Me Peace On Earth)&quot;.  The dramatic hymn &quot;Who Can See It&quot; vividly swells and soars to great heights, and is probably my favorite track.  The same can be said of the lavishly arranged &quot;Try Some, Buy Some&quot;, which was co-produced by Phil Spector.  &quot;Don't Let Me Wait Too Long&quot; is an infectious little pop gem that easily could have climbed to the top of the charts.  The album's title track is a good, solid, energy-packed rocker with hints of Indian mysticism.  One of the album's most popular tunes, &quot;Sue Me, Sue You Blues&quot;, written about the Beatles' breakup, is by far it's least spiritually-oriented.  It is an biting, emotionally driven rocker with a catchy melody and, like several of the album's tracks, excellent slide guitar playing by George.  <BR>     It has been complained of ad nauseum that George &quot;preaches&quot; too much on this album.  The fact is that the spiritual lyrics on songs like &quot;The Light That Has Lighted The World&quot; and the title track have far more to do with George's personal beliefs and inward journey than any kind of admonishment of the masses.  Furthermore, the music itself it was is really spiritual about this album, and such lyrics are merely a fitting compliment to its true &quot;message&quot;, which lies within the awesome beauty of the music.  As Harrison himself states in the disc's touching closer, appropriately entitled &quot;That Is All&quot;, &quot;silence often says much more than trying to say what's been said before&quot;.  So I'll let the music stand for itself...
B000001EYO|4.0|having read these other fine reviews by fellow fans of this excellent coen brothers film, i have to say i agree with many when i voice my disappointment at the exclusion of creedence's very dude-like \\"lookin' out my back door\\". though not so much of a problem for myself, being an owner of a copy of \\"cosmo's factory\\", i feel that many buyers may feel disheartened to learn of it's absence on the album. this however, is no reason at all not to go out there and buy the damn thing! from the trippy kenny rogers track to the soothing tones of dylan, and even the excellent gipsy king's take on the eagle's classic Hotel...<BR> this is a winning choice. chuck this on the hi fi and watch people's heads turn. if you've seen the film, then this album serves as great reminder of those hilarious and moving moments of bizarre adventure that the dude and his \\"jewish\\" 'nam veteran buddy walter embark upon....

B000002J0G|5.0|Low marks a new standard for Testament as they move forward with their sound bringing to it a heaviness and fury not heard before. It's not that Testament's other albums haven't been killer, they have, but in Low Chuck Billy really goes all out with the vocals and in some songs he employs the full death metal growl. He doesn't overuse the death-metal voice however, preferring to use it only for extra emphasis on some of the tracks.<BR>Lead guitarist Alex Skolnick is not present here, and though his signature sound is missed, Testament sounds none the worse for it, on the contrary, Skolnicks departure may have been the reason for this new heavier musical direction. As always, the band is not content to just play at hyper speed or simply downtune and distort their guitars beyond recognition of any musical structure as many other metal bands do. Testament has always delivered inventive songs and intelligent lyrics along with the bludgeoning riffs, and Low is no exception. A worthy addition to the Testament legacy.
B00004W50T|5.0|This album changed my life, changed the way i think about music, and opened my musical horizons.  From the first song, &quot;Tears of Rage&quot;, i was blown away by the passionate, tortured, and beautiful vocals of pianist Richard Manuel.  Some of the other highlights are the rocking &quot;Chest Fever&quot;, the emotionally powerful &quot;The Weight&quot;, and the crazy &quot;This Wheel's On Fire&quot;.<br />The musicianship on this album is incredible from all 5 members, with Garth Hudson on organ, Robbie Robertson on guitar, Rick Danko on bass, and Levon Helm on drums, including when they switch around instruments.  This album captures so many emotions and successfully merges so many American traditions in music.<br />In addition, the bonus tracks are great too.  It's cool to hear alternate versions of songs, as well as songs that weren't even on the album.  &quot;Orange Juice Blues&quot; is great, as well as &quot;Long Distance Operator&quot;.<br />This album has great liner notes which really provide insight into the workings of this (at the time) pretty mysterious band.  This album is well worth the cost, and the extra stuff you get makes the deal even sweeter.<br />This album might take a few listens before you really get into it, but it is well worth it, as this album is one of the greatest albums of the late 60s, and remains one of my favorites.

B000005J56|5.0|&quot;Buena Vista Social Club&quot; is the album that ignited my love affair with the rich and warm sounds of Cuban music.  The album's intricate melodies and impassioned vocals glide through these excellent tracks, all produced by Ry Cooder.  But while Cooder takes helm of the production, the real stars are the vocalists and the band members who breathe energy, feeling, and zest into this stellar recording.  The opener &quot;Chan Chan&quot; is a gentle and laid back number equipped with effective percussion, a spicy dash of guitars, and well-harmonized vocals from Eliades Ochoa, Compay Segundo, and Ibrahim Ferrer.  I was left in awe by the pretty melody of &quot;De Camino a La Vereda&quot; and the sharp trumpeting in &quot;El Cuarto de Tula.&quot;  But I was most impressed by the dynamite Ibrahim Ferrer who takes lead vocals in &quot;Candela,&quot; an uptempo number which soars due to tasty acoustic guitars and percussion.  Sensual, tender, emotional, and full of life, &quot;The Buena Vista Social Club&quot; is a towering and riveting experience.  It's a rare beauty that will leave you amazed.

0385720920|4.0|Chuck Palahniuk is a clunky idea stylist. I initially found the writing to be stilted and laborious but later warmed up to it. This is a quick read, even at near 300 pages. While the overall book does have some structure, most of it only becomes apparent after the 150 pages or so. Unfortunately, this makes the beginning feel like you're wallowing in misery along with the apathetic lead character - Victor Mancini.<br />Victor is like many people in that he's never really live up to his expectations. In fact, he's quit trying. He's a listless sex-addict with an addled mother in the hospital, a poor mindless daily job, a con-artist by evening, who has a friend with even less direction than himself.<br />Victor is happy to take the blame for other people's misfortune, even when he has nothing to do with it - a real sadomasochist. This story is about what happens when Victor's reality gets pulled out from under him and he has to come clean to everyone he's deluded - especially himself. It's also a story about inspiration and how it can be found in the strangest places. Stick through this one to the end. It's worth it. I would think that fans of Irvine Welsh would really like this book.
B000003S0D|5.0|_Lizard_, King Crimson's third studio album, is probably the most strange, surreal (musically and lyrically) and jazziest out of Crimson's 1970's period. It's also very fantasy-laden, ephemeral (in a good way), manic, quirky and idiosyncratic. The biggest contributing factor to this (beside the trippy and surreal jazz-rock), is the underrated and understated contributions of Gordon Haskell (vocals, bass). His dark, brooding and raspy vocals fit perfectly with the dark and regal music found on here. His glycyrrhiza glabra (licorice) pipes tend to produce a voice that's unique, idiosyncratic, magnanimous, chivalrous, kingly, regal and moving--almost a deeper-voiced, early incarnation of Peter Gabriel (whom may have been influenced by this album).<br />\\"Cirkus\\" starts off magically, then explodes into a forbidding nightmare of ominously gallant synthesizers and backdrops. The jazzy drumming of Andy McCulloch (or McCullogh, I've seen two different names, so I'm not sure which one is accurate), is also something to behold throughout the album. \\"Indoor Games\\" features tasteful r&b-esque guitar playing from Robert Fripp. Very idiosyncratic, ambiguous and almost indescribable jazz-rock tune. \\"Happy Family\\" is a \\"pandemonium\\" of dissonant unity amongst all the players: synths, flutes, guitars--and more. A real messy track (I mean that in the most flattering way). \\"Lady Of The Dancing Water\\" is a short, ethereal and mellow flute-laden track which brings reminiscence to Cadence And Cascade (from _In The Wake Of Poseidon_). Ironically, \\"Cadence\\" is the track Gordon Haskell sang vocals for. That raspy voice heard here sounds nothing like the mellow voice heard on that ditty found on the previous album. Arguably, this track also gives an utter hint of things to come on the follow-up album, _Islands_. \\"Lizard\\", the title track, is a 23-minute dark, jazzy/symphonic epic, featuring Jon Anderson (Yes) singing lead vocals for the first movement. Personally, I was saddened to know that Gordon Haskell didn't complete all the vocal duties. Jon Anderson does an excellent job on his vocals. I believe Gordon Haskell's vocals reappear somewhere near the end of the track. Other than that, a large percentage of this track is instrumental, moody and given to atmospherical spatiality.<br />_Lizard_ is definitely not an album to skip in the King Crimson catalog (are any of them?). If quirky, theatrical, bizarre, manic, complex jazz-rock with symphonic touches appeals to you, pick this up. Also, pick this up if you like the bizarre antics of the Gabriel-era Genesis. The bizarre and theatrical elements of this disc may have influenced Peter Gabriel and his contributions to Genesis. (Side Note: I believe ALL of the Caroline 30th anniversary studio remasters feature the lyrics to Crimsons's songs).t Gordon Haskell didn't complete all the vocal duties. Jon Anderson does an excellent job on his vocals. I believe Gordon Haskell's vocals reappear somewhere near the end of the track. Other than that, a large percentage of this track is instrumental, moody and given to atmospherical spatiality.<br />_Lizard_ is definitely not an album to skip in the King Crimson catalog (are any of them?). If quirky, theatrical, bizarre, manic, complex jazz-rock with symphonic touches appeals to you, pick this up. Also, pick this up if you like the bizarre antics of the Gabriel-era Genesis. The bizarre and theatrical elements of this disc may have influenced Peter Gabriel and his contributions to Genesis. (Side Note: I believe ALL of the Caroline 30th anniversary studio remasters feature the lyrics to Crimsons's songs).
B000002G8H|4.0|Slowhand is clearly one of Eric Clapton's stronger solo releases. Whereas there are plenty of guitar solos and effects, many of these tunes are quite pleasing. A little bit mellow but certainly quite focused.<br />The lead off track, Cocaine features a very distnictive riff and steady instrumental support. Like the gutiar solo in the middle. Wonderful Tonight will always be known as a classic wedding song. One of Eric's best compositions. Lay Down Sally features some mellow guitar picking and a nice chugging rhythm. Next Time You See Her features some good drumming by Jaime Oldaker in addition to some tasty guitar licks. We're All The Way is a pleasant focused ballad.<br />The second half kicks off with a riveting duet between Eric and Marcy Levy on the Core. Super guitar solos by George Terry and Eric as well as a good saxaphone break by Mel Collins. May You Never is a catchy tune with cute vocal styling by Eric. Mean Old Frisco is a fine blues number and Peaches And Diesel is a pretty instrumental with touching guitar parts.<br />A solid if not overly spectacular release that showcases the mellow side of Eric Clapton.

B00006V9A0|2.0|The remaining members of Nirvana wanted the bands previously unreleased gem \\"You Know You're Right\\" to be released with a batch of other rarities in a box set of \\"new\\" material.  Cobain's widow, Courtney Love, wanted to be able to use Nirvana's name and the much-hyped new tune as a bargaining chip in a new deal with Universal Records.  She won in the courts, and now the song has been tacked on as the obligitory new track on a collection of 13 songs that have been released and heard a million times before.<br />Nirvana doesn't lend itself well to compilation because they only released 3 albums that each sound very, very different.  It's not very expensive and a much more rewarding decision to buy each of the three albums rather than this cheesy \\"Greatest Hits\\" record, something it's hard to imagine a living Kurt Cobain authorizing.  The songs are good, but a lot of the groups best work is missing here and the arrangement leaves a lot to be desired.
B00006CXXU|5.0|I am Christina Aguilera fan, I admit it. I have always been in love with her voice and have so much respect for it.  Her first LP was indeed very teen-booper and record-company laid out.  Christina had a chance to show the world she had a great voice but unfortunately on her octaves were heard, not her emotions. Overall this album is relatively flawless, every song has a special meaning and is very well produced and arranged.  There are absolutely no fillers.  If you appreciate music even if you dont like Christina...this CD is definitely worth the [money]. Please don't miss out on great effort by a woman that has so much to say.

Why the need for the zoological prologue that consumes so much paper in this book?  Why is the divine so desperately sought by a child? Why is Piscine's following statement &quot;pointless?&quot;<BR>  &quot;It is pointless to say that this or that night was the worst of my life. I have so many bad nights to choose from that I've made none the champion.&quot; <BR>   Find one of these and you may find why this book has so infected subtle readers for the breeze by which it sails and to all others for the airy telling of a good tale that admonishes both sorts that; &quot;This story has a happy ending.&quot;<BR>At last, the author opens up both the characters and the reader to accept whichever fiction they choose to believe and isn't that, ultimately, what each of us do all of time anyway?  That this fiction is stranger than truth...it may not be stranger at all.  It may be exactly what one needs to see why this yarn of anthropomorphic delight cuts to the marrow and extracts the pith of what the reader already possesses.<br />I am not certain if the author even knew all this writing was pointing toward.

B00006CXXU|4.0|Every Christina Aguilera record has become an event worth anticipating, if only for the reason that shes one of the few young women in the business at the moment who can actually sing. While 'Stripped' technically is her fifth album (counting her debut 'Christina Aguilera', 'My Kind of Christmas', 'Mi Reflejo', and the unauthorized 'Just be Free'), its clearly the most polished, most slick and decidedly the best solo female record since Madonna's 'Music' a few years ago. However, while that record was criticized for being too short, this one excels in that department. Clocking in at 80 minutes, 'Stripped' is one of the longest single-disc-CDs ever released, and makes its mark by giving us one quality track after another.<br />Christina's strength has always been her voice and its clear that she respects this talent. The songs all showcase her breathtaking vocals, and save for the single 'Dirrty', this is probably an album you could gift your aunt or grandmother who has a fondness for Aretha Franklin. Yes, its THAT good and that diverse. I'm especially picky about pop music these days and tend to steer clear of 'teen-pop' as the entire genre reeks of Occidental marketing at its' worst, but when a quality product such as 'Stripped' hits the shelves, you can't help but notice.<br />The range the singer displays on this record is amazing. It bears mentioning that after the release of this album, any comparisons to moppet Spears will prove nonsensical. In places, the songstress reminded my of Gladys Knight and the Pips, and some of the melodies hark back to the era of the Supremes. Like I said earlier, the fact that this is a very varied record gives it that much more credibility. If you liked Alicia Keyes' 'Songs' album, you will undoubtedly fall in love with this one. Its much better that Keyes' effort simply because it bears no signs of confusion or directionlessness. Each track flows into the next with ease, and the result is a sparkling pop masterpiece that is well worth anyone's time.<br />Lead single 'Dirrty' turns out to be the weak spot on the album. While it is certainly a mediocre tune, it sounds much better on CD that one would image. The track is multilayered with instrumentation that is completely lost in the music video. The album has its fair share of ballads (especially the soaring 'Beautiful', and the poignant 'Walk Away'). There are Pink-tinged tunes such as 'Underappreciated' and 'Make Over' and even a collaboration with L'il Kim that isn't as bad as one would think. While Christina has collaborated with a multitude of performers, at no stage is it a case of 'took many cooks spoil the broth'. And I cannot remember the last time an album had no 'fillers'. At the end of it, I felt I had listened to an ALBUM, which is more than I can say for other new artists such as Avril Lavigne or Jessica Simpson.<br />'Stripped' could get five stars, but I'm holding out on one star due to the image that Christina has chosen to portray. Granted that a beautiful young woman has every right to flaunt it, but this may serve to alienate listeners who would, for example, also listen to Norah Jones 'Come Away with Me' (my personal favorite of the year so far). If the image wasn't so tarty, 'Stripped' could well been the musical story of the year.<br />There are a few albums that share the same qualities and vibe that 'Stripped' does : 'Janet' by Janet Jackson, 'Come Away with me' by Norah Jones, 'Misunderstood' by Pink, and 'Eli and the Thirteenth Confession' by Laura Nyro. It also has the same spirit that Courtney Love's band Hole sported on their last album. This is a very urban and contemporary record, yet it has its own classic, almost jazz-like flavor.<br />If you are looking for one album this year that covers all musical genres and delivers on the vocal front, let it be this one. And in case you were always somewhat interested in what young people these days were listening to, give this one a listen. It may open doors to areasof new musical interest for you.of new musical interest for you.
B00003CX9Q|5.0|After much waiting, ET finally comes \\"home\\" on DVD ! <br />I have to say that I was really looking forward for this much loved movie to come on DVD so I can add it to my collection. Growing up, ET has always had a special place in my heart and mind as being one of the very first films that touched me deeply. I have to admit that the first time I revisited the movie after 20 years, I still tear up at the same scenes as I did when I was 10 watching the original release in the local cinema.<br />The DVD itself is a real value buy. Having both the 2002 and original release in the same package is brilliant! The picture and sound quality is astounding for a film that is 20 years old. I didn't really think that the new additions in the 2002 release made ET any less enjoyable than the original. To me, they just added a little more detail to the viewing experience. In truth, I'm just happy that ET finally is on DVD.<br />The extras included in this package are appropriate enough for this movie. Most telling are the mini featurettes on the ET 20th Anniversary Premier and the cast reunion. I have yet to go through the production slide show but from little I've seen of it, it was a very comprehensive collection. I didn't see any menu link for a commentary track so I assume that it wasn't included. I wished that it was as such a significant movie like ET deserves one ... especially one from the cast and director. We are only given a little bit of the thought process that went into the creation of the movie from the featurettes that would really be well recieved if it was expended into a commetary track.<br />On the minus side, I thought that the DVD case design was a bit ill concieved. It felt flimsy and may even fall apart after a few years. I wished that they had made a better DVD case for this package that would not only look good on the shelves but also able to protect this precious movie for a long time. In fact, I would mind paying a bit more if they released this packagein a metal DVD case like the one that Akira Special Edition (ASIN: B00005MAM2) came in.<br />All in all, this is one DVD that is well worth the wait. After 20 years, we can now return to the same sense of wonder that we experience watching how simple things was for a boy and his new best \\"friend\\". Uncluttered by the difference that divide them, the two characters manage to bridge the gap and form a lasting bond. I wished that more people would take this lesson to heart in this day and age.<br />As a conclusion, this DVD package is a real good value for money purchase to add to your collection.

B000002LQQ|4.0|As a long time fan, it's hard for me to really consider this a Dire Straits album. \\"On Every Street\\" is a departure in two ways: the most obvious, of course, is that it's the band's last album. The second is the new and different sound Mark has created. With the exception of \\"Heavy Fuel\\" and \\"The Bug\\" revisiting familiar territory from \\"Brothers In Arms\\" this release embraces more styles  and influences than you'd ever expect from a standard DS release. The new, more polished sound is a perfect evolution for Mark, but seems a little out of character for the rest of the band. For these reasons, \\"On Every Street\\" seems more like Mark Knopfler's first solo album than his band's swan song. That said, some of my favorite work from the band is on this CD. \\"Planet of New Orleans,\\" \\"Fade to Black,\\" \\"When it Comes to You,\\" \\"You and Your Friend\\" and \\"On Every Street\\" are not only good, they're classics. Unfortunately there are a couple throw-aways in the mix as well. \\"Heavy Fuel\\" is a shameless, less clever, poor man's version of \\"Money for Nothing\\" and \\"Calling Elvis,\\" while a serviceable tune, is about five minutes too long. \\"My Parties\\" is fun, but not anything you'll need to hear more than once. However, the vast majority of the tracks are gems and over all this album is a must-have for anyone moved by Mark's work.

B00006CXXU|4.0|Okay, okay! She does create an image of just another 'tart' singing trite pop songs, but there is more to Christina Aguilera than meets the eye---surprising though that might be from her image. The quality that sets her apart is that she holds in her possession an incredible instrument in her voice. She is not just another pop singer or teen idol. She deserves to be recognized as a singer who is in the league of the Holy Trinity of new female soul singers (Kelly Price, Faith Evans and Mary J. Blige). Though scantily clad, her full body voice adds some layers to a seemingly shallow singer. <br />The disc offers up some incredible songs and vocals. The only drawback to the disc is the choice of some of the material (the Linda Perry written tracks) and the fact that Christina can over-sing at times. \\"Walk Away\\" is a powerful, brooding blues record that would make Etta James proud and Christina seems perfectly at home in that genre as well. The latin-tinged \\"Infatuation\\", complete with spanish guitar is another on which the singer shines. It's also a genre with which Christina seems comfortable..see 2000's stunning 'Mi Reflejo'. The disc presses on with the romantic, mature \\"Loving Me For Me\\". To follow this is the Alicia Keys composed \\"Impossible\\". Alicia certainly has done her homework on the Queen of Soul, Aretha. This track seems to be the combination of three classic Aretha songs. The airy piano opening hearkens back to the Regent's opening of the classic \\"Daydreamin\\" while the body of the song seems more inspired by Franklin classics \\"Ain't No Way\\" and \\"Natural Woman\\". In spite of these interpolations, or perhaps because of them, the solitary thing that makes this record so outstanding is Christina's powerhouse vocal. Other inspired tracks include \\"Underappreciated\\", the majestic \\"Soar\\" and the raunchy, adult \\"Get Mine, Get Yours\\". Not only has she matured as an artist, but this disc heralds the advent of the woman that she has become.<br />There are, however, songs that are not suited for the singer at all. Most notably among these tracks is \\"Dirrty\\". It's a great song to dance to at a club, but it does it does nothing for Christina in the way of displaying her actual talents. Additionally, the Linda Perry penned tracks don't seem to hit home either as Christina does not seem capable of singing rock songs. And the failed studio experiment \\"Can't Hold Us Down\\" (which features the ever torrid Lil Kim) sees Christina offering up garbled, slurred vocals which are reminiscent of the lesser-talented Beyonce Knowles.<br />In all, this disc is one of the best Pop/Soul records to be released this year. Christina's powerhouse voice and the great production of this album seem the perfect vehicle to catapult this singer into being the Diva that she wishes to become. Don't be fooled by her outward appearance. The girl can sing and actually has talents, though her manner of dress would lead you to believe that she'd rather you didn't know.
B00006V9A0|5.0|I don't think i need to say a whole lot here. Nirvana was one of the best bands ever, and this is a collection of their best songs. I hope you don't need to be convinced to buy it. But if you do, here goes:  this CD has everything a rock fan could want (tortured vocals and lyrics, hard riffs, melodic ballads, etc.), it is a worthy representation of the band that revolutionized modern rock, and I'd list the many more reasons if i didn't procratinate on my social studies project that is due tomorrow. Just buy the friggin' CD.

B00006CXXU|5.0|Christina Aguilera's follow-up to her debut album is amazing, for lack of a better word.  On &quot;Christina Aguilera&quot;, Christina was strugglig with vocal gymnastics and couldn't quite find her niche.  It was a great album, but it was too sugar-coated and sweet for anyone to listen to repeatedly for a great amount of time.  Now,though, Christina has come back with vengeance.  She mixes jazz, rock, and pop to create a unique, flawless album.  She has certainly grown up, swearing in &quot;Make Over&quot; and thanking a past lover for giving her strength in &quot;Fighter&quot;.  <BR>Comparisons with Mariah Carey are inevitable, for Christina is the only artist since Mariah to show so much talent.  Also noteworthy is the fact that she actually co-writes the songs.  Few artists are willing to stray from he cookie-cutter mold of a pop artist.  However, these artists are unable to move with time.  Christina's album shows that she wants to make timeless music..and she has succeeded in doing so.

B00006CXXU|5.0|This album is a great album. There is no \\"pop tart\\" type stuff that Britany Spears seems to have stuck with. B000006TRV|5.0|\\"The Wall,\\" Pink Floyd's 1979 concept album about a rock star's mental breakdown, is a towering monster. It's an album with SO many audio, lyrical, musical & emotional nooks and crannies contained within, that one listen simply will not cut it. \\"The Wall\\" is not just an album to listen to, it's an album to be *explored*. It was inspired by then-bandleader Roger Waters' own mental collapse at the end of the Floyd's tour for the \\"Animals\\" album. Due to the grind of the mammoth stadium tour for \\"Animals,\\" and sickened by seeing his own band, in his opinion, become part of the rock business \\"circus,\\" Waters was mentally & emotionally exhausted beyond comprehension. At the final gig in Montreal, Waters finally snapped, spitting in the face of a young fan sitting up front. Coming home to England to recover, Waters finally decided to exorcise his demons by writing a conceptual piece about his disgust with his life as a rock star, and he began building \\"The Wall\\"....With the bulk of the double-album composed by Waters (with a few co-writing contributions from guitarist David Gilmour & producer Bob Ezrin), \\"The Wall\\" tells the story of a rock star named Pink and his downward spiral into madness, and all the things in his life that led him there: his father killed in the war when he was only a baby (\\"Another Brick In The Wall Part 1\\"), being smothered by his overbearing mother (\\"Mother\\"), subjected to abuse at school (\\"The Happiest Days Of Our Lives\\"/\\"Another Brick In The Wall Part 2\\"), and later, the pressures of his rock-star lifestyle (\\"One Of My Turns\\") and the breakdown of his marriage (\\"Don't Leave Me Now\\"). Quite simply, \\"The Wall\\" is a rock masterwork, and arguably Roger Waters' greatest achievement as a composer. However, to think of the album simply as a \\"Roger Waters production\\" would be wrong. Though Waters IS, indeed, the main architect of \\"The Wall,\\" bravely wearing his heart on his sleeve with his powerful songwriting and tortured singing (not to mention playing a mean bass throughout), the album still would not be what it is without the excellent contributions of guitarist/vocalist David Gilmour, who also shines on tracks like the smash hit, \\"Another Brick In The Wall Part 2\\" (featuring his most famous guitar solo ever recorded with the band), \\"Goodbye Blue Sky,\\" \\"Young Lust,\\" \\"Hey You\\" and \\"Comfortably Numb\\" (featuring yet another classic Gilmour guitar solo). Keyboardist Richard Wright & drummer Nick Mason are, admittedly, dwarfed somewhat on \\"The Wall\\" by the inclusion of various session players (that's Jeff Porcaro playing drums on \\"Mother,\\" to name one example). Still, Mason & Wright appear often enough, and they make their contributions count. The production on \\"The Wall\\" is also astounding---from the great stereophonic mix of the tunes themselves, to the treasure trove of sound effects & voices (such as fighter planes, helicopters, objects being smashed, singing schoolchildren, a telephone operator, a TV set playing \\"Gomer Pyle,\\" and on and on), \\"The Wall\\" is truly a listening *experience*. Thankfully, Roger Waters, having left Pink Floyd in 1983, is living quite comfortably these days, no longer bothered by his rock star demons, and he continues to make great music on his own (he's also much more appreciative of his live audiences these days, thank goodness). Obviously for Waters, making \\"The Wall\\" was much-needed therapy. For Pink Floyd, \\"The Wall\\" became one of the group's biggest best-sellers, second only to \\"Dark Side Of The Moon.\\" For the listener, \\"The Wall\\" is a spellbinding musical journey. It's music is at turns beautiful, haunting, and unquestionably powerful, and it's story is an absolutely gripping one. \\"The Wall\\" is a timeless, undisputed Pink Floyd classic.
630233683X|5.0|i think Singin' in the Rain is the best musical ever! everyone should see it. its funny, has a great plot, and a fabulous cast. I've seen it atleast ten times now, and i still love it, i could honestly watch it over and over again.

There's also &quot;Soar&quot;, which has some Dixie-Chicks-ish harmony at the beginning, and &quot;Impossible&quot;, which sounds exactly how you would expect an Alicia Keys song to sound.  <br />All in all, it's a great melange with the strength and versatility of Christina's vocals throughout.  I think a lot of people will be surprised by the depth of the album, given the weak material of her first album.  It's such a welcome change to hear her singing material worthy of her voice!

B00006RINF|5.0|The Coil is back and has lost none of the steam they built up when releasing the excellent &quot;Unleashed Memories,&quot; coming back with this superb collection of 13 tracks of loneliness, introspection, and sadness, simultaneously managing to make them catchy and &quot;sing-along-with-able.&quot; [How's that for a made-up-on-the-spot term?]  <br />There seems to be even more of a &quot;metal&quot; feel to this one than there was on &quot;Memories,&quot; and male vocalist Andrea gets to do a little more on vocals than he did previously, though of course he sounds best when harmonizing with the often haunting, often sultry, and always intoxicating vocals of female vocalist Cristina Scabbia. (And as an added bonus, she's cute, too.)  <br />Creative touches abound, such as the unusual &quot;CD Skip&quot; effect in the middle of &quot;Aeon&quot; and the &quot;radio vocal&quot; samples in songs like &quot;Angel's Punishment&quot; and &quot;Tight Rope.&quot;  Keyboards are prevalent, but never overwhelm the often-VERY-heavy guitar sound or the vocal interplay.  <br />Production is spectacular all the way through. High points are difficult to pick out because the whole album is so well-done, though &quot;Swamped&quot; and &quot;Daylight Dancer&quot; are my current faves after about five listens.  Comparing this to the other Coil albums, it's already my second favorite and rapidly closing in on &quot;Unleashed Memories.&quot;<br />Bottom Line: I had high hopes for this album.  Usually when I set such high standards based on a previous release, I get disappointed.  Not this time.  The Coil delivers a masterwork of melodic, gothic metal that is NOT to be missed if you're a fan of the style.  Now if only they'd TOUR here in the U.S.!

B00003CXCW|5.0|Not without reason is this one of the greatest films of all time. Never before had anyone dared to expose the seedy, depressing underside of the Hollywood rat race and no one has come close since( with the possible exception of Robert Altman, whose film The Player makes for a great double feature). Billy Wilder's tale of a far too original for his own good, down on his luck screenwriter who finds shelter in the home and arms of a delusional, washed up silent movie queen is the kind of story Recyclewood(TM) could only dream of making these days. Everything about this film works. The dialogue is sharp, biting and often humorous. The players are all cast perfectly, whether it be Gloria Swanson's silent era goddess Norma Desmond, William Holden's disillusioned writer Joe Gillis or former silent era director Erich Von Stroheim's turn as Norma's ex-husband/butler Max. Even the bit players are brilliant. Including Cecil B. DeMille as himself and former Hollywood legends H.B. Warner, Buster Keaton and Anna Q. Nilsson as Norma's bridge cronies(aka \\"waxworks\\"). The cinematography is beautifully flawless, especially within the confines of Norma Desmond's cavernous home. And the directing, well, it's Billy Wilder and he could do no wrong. If you are thinking about a career in the glittering shark tank, this is as good a cautionary tale as you'll ever see.

B00006CXXU|5.0|She's always said that there was more to her as a person and a vocalist and an artist than what we saw.  So it's no surprise that people are so surprised by the \\"sharp turn\\" that her first single conveyed (\\"Dirrty\\").  <BR>She serves some confections that shed all ties to teen pop, a genre that Ms. Aguilera has declined since her entrance.  More than that, Aguilera asserts herself as a strong artist as well as a vocalist by co-executive producing and writing all but two of the songs featured on this album.  With a wide breadth on the spectrum of producers, her artistic presence unifies a stylistically erratic album that is moving, believable and grooveworthy.<BR>The album opens with \\"Stripped Pt. 1,\\" a re-introduction to an artist we thought we knew, followed by \\"Can't Hold Us Down,\\" a hip-hop infused barb (featuring Lil' Kim) directed to men whose misogyny overtakes their senses, inspired by her own experiences with rumors and double-standards.  Christina cannot \\"Walk Away\\" from a love that doesn't love her the way that she needs in a soulful ballad but turns on the anger in the Dave Navarro guitar-featuring rocker, \\"Fighter.\\"  \\"Infatuation\\" and its preceding interlude are the stories of Christina's first love in Spanglish and flamenco rhythm while in the Mariah-like \\"Loving Me 4 Me\\" tells a tale of a lover who adores her without pretense.  The blues-drenched, Alicia Keys compositon shares the \\"Impossible\\" story of a lover who won't share with the woman that he loves and the next song is about the way the Christina's boyfriend has made her feel funky, but \\"Underappreciated.\\"   \\"Make Over\\" is a Linda Perry co-production addresses Christina's disdain for being a pop puppet then she barrels into critics who disapproved of her style, then translating it into a univeralizing anthem of self-love in \\"Beautiful.\\"  Linda Perry co- produced/wrote the next three songs: \\"Beautiful,\\" an introspection of the critiques she received on her style which transforms into a universalizing, touch song, anthem of self-love and self-reliance; \\"Make Over\\" features Christina addressing her disdain for having been a pop puppet in a retro production; \\"Cruz\\" is a high-flying song expressing the emotional perils of leaving today to find a better tomorrow.  Transcendence of others' expectations to fulfilling one's desires for self, that is the message in \\"Soar\\" but \\"Get Mine, Get Yours\\" is a neo-soul treatise to a lover who is having trepidation with their relationship status' nonextance.  \\"Dirrty\\" is the party anthem of any 21-year-old who wants to shake their ... with Redman and Rockwilder.  Then, \\"the Voice Within\\" is co- produced/written by Glen Ballard (of Alanis Morrisette, No Doubt fame) ballad that promotes self-assuredness over a fear of flight.  \\"I'm OK\\" is describes some of the traumas that Christina endured as the child of an abusive father in the form of a heartfelt and tear-jerking (she is literally crying on the track) ballad.  And \\"Keep On Singin' My Song\\" is a celebration of Christina's survival.<BR>Wrought with themes of thriving beyond adversity, independence, being a woman, and love, Christina's album isn't teen pop anymore.  It's adult music for adult people by an adult with a lot to say and a gifted voice and an amazing capacity for articulation.
B00006NSZ5|5.0|This CD is one of the best rap compilations I have ever bought.  The shining tracks on the album are Lose Yourself (the newest Eminem song on the radio and the most meaningful), 8 Mile, Run Rabbit Run (a fast song that really gets you pumping), Love Me (which is a slow song that truly does Eminem's lyrics justice, how can you not love this song?), Rap Game (D12 sound great on this song and their rhymes are tight), 8 Miles and Running (it's Jay Z what else can I say), and a song by Boomkat called Wasting My Time (the song is beautiful and eerily haunting).  I think that anyone who is an Eminem fan should go out and get this album right away, if it's any indication of how the movie's going to be I can't wait.
0312958455|4.0|Michael Connelly has dusted off an increasingly rare gemstone in the crown jewels of American literature: the hard-boiled detective. Present in Connelly's pithy and believable prose is all of the wit and grit of Hammett, MacDonald, Stout, and Spillane. What he's brought us in Harry Bosch is a cop's cop. Bosch, an LAPD homicide detective, is a real-life hero for whom the principled drive to see justice done allows him to deal with the treacherous world of Los Angeles politics and some even more treacherous politicians (some of whom masquerade as police officials). <br />While _The Last Coyote_ is the fourth Bosch novel, the plot and characters are so artfully developed that this novel could stand alone as a complete novel. At the same time, the writing is so compelling and captivating that it is a real pleasure to know that Bosch is a recurring character in Connelly's work. Although this is my first Connelly story, I am officially an addict, and I cannot wait to devour the rest of the titles in the Bosch series. <br />_The Last Coyote_ opens with Bosch under suspension for assaulting his Commanding Officer, Harvey \\"98\\" Pounds. With his newfound freedom comes a mandatory psychiatric evaluation to determine his fitness as a police officer. The ensuing therapy sessions force Bosch to take a hard look at his options, should he later be kicked off the force for the assault on his CO. <br />Faced with his ever-present personal demons, his suspension, and time on his hands, Bosch begins to investigate perhaps his greatest mystery: the unsolved 1961 murder of his call-girl mother. Though cautioned by his therapist that solving this mystery may remove his motivation to be a detective, Bosch dives into a mystery (and his personal story) that exposes the seedy underside of Los Angeles political corruption. The ride is taut, human, and utterly engrossing, and we are at once deeply satisfied and virtually winded when the dust settles. <br />My introduction to Harry Bosch was oneof those rare joys: a gifted writer spinning a fascinating tale with grace and skill. Perhaps equally enjoyable to me was the principled drive of the protagonist to get at the facts, despite the potential costs-to himself, his career, and his department. Bosch's belief that the truth shall set you free is more than a bromide. While freedom may not always bring redemption, it allows him to sleep at night.

The shining tracks on the album are Lose Yourself (the newest Eminem song on the radio and the most meaningful), 8 Mile, Run Rabbit Run (a fast song that really gets you pumping), Love Me (which is a slow song that truly does Eminem's lyrics justice, how can you not love this song?), Rap Game (D12 sound great on this song and their rhymes are tight), 8 Miles and Running (it's Jay Z what else can I say), and a song by Boomkat called Wasting My Time (the song is beautiful and eerily haunting).  I think that anyone who is an Eminem fan should go out and get this album right away, if it's any indication of how the movie's going to be I can't wait.

B00005AXEL|5.0|First of all, I would like to say that it is a major dissapointment to me that this album only when \\"gold\\" and was not the mega hit I was hoping for! However, this is not due to the music on this album, which I must say is amazing! The problem is that people haven't given Trouble In Shangri-La much of a chance, perhaps due to the disaster that was Street Angel, here are some reasons why you should:<br />1. Stevie sounds better than she has in years on these songs. Yes, her voice has changed, but it has changed for the better. It's every bit as expressive and emotional as before.<BR>2. The songs are excellent. Stand out tracks include the title track, Planets of the Universe, Sorcerer, It's Only Love, Bombay Sapphires, Fall from Grace, Too Far From Texas, and Love Is. The other tracks are excellent as well, but these are some of Stevie's best songs EVER.<BR>3. Even if you are not a Stevie fan, give this album a try. If you like good music that has substance and meaning you will like this I promise you. <BR>Trouble in Shangri-La has something for everyone, from country tunes to ballads to rockers, it is an impressive, stellar, and varied body of work. Buy it!
